title: Understanding Different Forms of Sugar
content: The conversation begins by defining the various forms of sugar, delineating between added sugar and naturally occurring sugar, and describing the important variables that determine the potential for metabolic damage from consumption. Glucose, Galactose, Fructose, Sucrose, and Allulose are all forms of sugar. Glucose and fructose are monomers — they form the simplest building blocks of carbohydrates. They even have the same chemical formula — same number of carbons, hydrogens, and oxygen. The difference is glucose is arranged in a six carbon ring, whereas fructose is arranged in a five carbon ring. This seemingly small difference makes all the difference in the world when it comes to their metabolic effects.

title: Sugar Consumption: Density, Volume, and Velocity
content: Important variables related to sugar consumption include density, volume, and velocity. Density refers to the concentration of sugar in a given volume, for example, a dried mango versus a whole mango. Volume refers to the actual quantity you consume. Velocity refers to the speed at which you consume sugar. All these factors play a role in the potential for metabolic damage from sugar consumption.

title: Sugar Substitutes
content: The discussion also covers three main categories of sugar substitutes—non-nutritive sweeteners, alcohol sugars, and allulose. Each of these substitutes has a different safety profile, impact on blood sugar and insulin, side-effects, and taste preferences.

title: Understanding Food Labels
content: Food labels list both sugar and added sugar. However, it's important to understand that 'naturally occurring' sugar in foods like dried mangoes can be just as harmful as 'added sugar' in products like soda. The misconception is that the dried mango is somehow healthy and the coke is terrible. There’s really no difference in the carbohydrate molecules of sugar found in fruits or HFCS but the soluble fiber in the (non-dried) fruit stabilizes blood sugar.

title: Sugar Metabolism and Health
content: How quickly do the molecules of sugar make their way out of the stomach and into ultimately the upper part of the duodenum, where they’re functionally going to come in contact with your liver? — that is the question of velocity. With fructose, the “heavy lifting” from a metabolism standpoint is going to be done in the liver. You have a whole mango, and you simply dry it out (remove all the water), it’s just becomes a mass balance equation — it’s now much more dense. If all you’ve given up is water and going from a regular mango to a dried mango, what you’re probably changing is the speed with which it might hit the liver. Additionally, going from whole mango to dried mango allows you to consume much more (volume).

title: Effects of Smoothies on Health
content: Smoothies are an example of when velocity/speed is a big issue. Smoothies and juicing are a “farce” and a “fiasco” because really your packing it so much fruit that would be impossible to eat whole and blending it into a liquid.

title: Exercise and Health
content: Exercise can help to mitigate the damage of eating the worst types of food. However, at some point you will go past the metabolic breaking point.

title: Alternatives to Sugar: Non-nutritive Sweeteners
content: Non-nutritive sweeteners either don’t have calories, or they do have calories, but they’re so much sweeter than sucrose that you’re using them in micro doses. Alcohol sugars have more calories than others, and they have some advantages to them. Allulose is a molecule that stands in its own place, which is itself a sugar. It meets all the sort of structural classifications of a sugar, but it doesn’t behave like sugar.

title: Alternatives to Sugar: Alcohol Sugars
content: Alcohol sugars are all monosaccharides — ‘naturally occurring’ things. Sorbitol and xylitol are caloric. Xylitol is basically matched in sweetness to sucrose. Whereas sorbitol is actually about half to two-thirds as sweet as sucrose. In fact, sorbitol is not even a “low-calorie” food, because if you actually want to get the same sweetness, you’re actually going to bring the caloric value right up to that of sucrose. Erythritol, on the other hand, is actually quite a low-calorie sweetener because it’s about 0.2 kilocalories per gram and it’s almost as sweet as sucrose (60% to 80%).

title: Alternatives to Sugar: Allulose
content: Allulose is actually a sugar (unlike the non-nutritive sweeteners or the polyols). It’s about 70% as sweet as sucrose. It’s chemical structure is the mirror image of fructose (an enantiomer) — a small difference that makes a HUGE impact. When you ingest it, it’s fully absorbed by the intestines which means: i) you do not get any GI distress ii) It’s effectively completely excreted by the kidneys. An animal study in rats reported that allulose only contributes to 0.3% of the energy deposit in animals.

title: Sodium-Glucose Co-Transporter-2 Inhibitors and Cancer
content: A 2019 meta-analysis study of sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 inhibitors (SGLT-2i) and cancer was referenced to reason the risk profile. The safety profile of this was deemed comfortable.

title: Cooking with Allulose
content: Allulose browns when heated which can affect the look of the end product. However, it is a good alternative to sugar when baking sweet things.

title: Risk Contextualization for Sugar Substitutes
content: The decision for which alternative to sugar to consume comes down to taste and preference, as there's not much chronic or acute toxicity for any of them. Aspartame is considered safe due to the overwhelming amount of data on it.

title: Non-Nutritive Sweeteners and Health
content: Some people report feeling better or losing weight when eliminating non-nutritive sweeteners from their diet. Possible explanations include increased appetite due to aspartame, disruption of the gut biome by non-nutritive sweeteners, or a psychological component related to making healthier choices.

title: Cephalic Insulin Response and Metabolic Drive
content: Cephalic phase responses (CPRs) occur in response to eating-associated cues but before any actual nutrient absorption. Cephalic phase insulin responses (CPIRs) occur when the pancreas begins to secrete insulin before a meal actually gets into the bloodstream. The impact of artificial sweeteners on these responses is unclear.

title: Impact of Sweetness on Metabolism
content: A recent experiment found that mice still prefer to consume a sugar sweetened beverage even when their sugar sensing abilities are knocked out. This is believed to be due to the metabolic demands of sugar. The same experiment found that mice that lost their ability to taste still developed metabolic syndrome even when consuming less sugar.
